repnme.cdata!: Croatia - Social and Economic Recovery Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Social and Economic
            Recovery Project for Croatia were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory and
            borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: like most demand driven
            community-based investments, the project required about two
            years before substantial disbursements could be made.
            Combining the 'top down' and 'bottom up'
            approaches was effective for implementing this demand driven
            social development investment. Grant financing is
            particularly useful to small enterprises when there are
            transitory constraints in the financial system. In a project
            where grant allocations will be made to applicants on a
            competitive basis, it is important to ensure that the
            selection takes into account that the applicant has the
            necessary permits and licenses. Community-based,
            demand-driven subprojects are sustainable. Monitoring and
            evaluation systems must be carefully designed to ensure that
            monitoring efforts can start early in the project
            implementation period and produce data that can be useful
            for assessing project outcomes and impacts. In a
            post-conflict situation, a demining component can be used
            strategically to unlock local economic potential and promote
            social cohesion.

Croatia - Social and Economic

15235247.trustfund:
BBFAO-BB FAO,TF041042-CROATIA - SOCIAL ECONOMIC
            RECOVERY PROGRAM - PREPARATION,TF050513-PHRD-CROATIA: SOCIAL AND
            ECONOMIC RECOVERY PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            restoring livelihoods in Croatia. Fifteen years after the
            end of hostilities in Croatia some people still lived in
            areas where roads, buildings and the water supply were
            destroyed and the land was littered with mines. Jobs were
            scarce. The Social and Economic Recovery Project created lot
            of job opportunities. Social and economic cohesion had also
            improved along with trust among different groups, which
            resulted in community driven, bottom-up and people-centered
            development in the country.

repnme.cdata!:
Economic and social revitalization and
            reintegration of Croatia’s war affected and disadvantaged areas

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about
            economic and social revitalization and reintegration of
            Croatia’s war affected and disadvantaged areas. The bleak
            economic situation, unemployment, destroyed infrastructure,
            and landmine contamination in the post-conflict areas were
            the main impediments to sustainable well-being of the
            war-affected groups. The Croatia Social and Economic
            Recovery Project supported the rehabilitation of small-scale
            social and economic infrastructure in the areas of return,
            and demining activities benefitting around eighty four
            thousand people.

repnme.cdata!:
Helping Croatia Prepare for Successful
            European Union Integration

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about helping
            Croatia prepare for successful European Union (EU)
            integration. Croatia’s overarching priority was to enter the
            EU with a competitive and growing economy and the
            institutional capacity to meet the demands of EU membership.
            To achieve this, several challenges needed to be overcome,
            including completing Croatia’s transition to a market
            economy with a focus on private sector growth. International
            Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD) has been
            focusing its assistance on helping Croatia prepare for
            successful EU integration by, raising the competitiveness of
            the economy through long-term investments in major trading
            routes such as the Ports of Rijeka and Ploce. IBRD has been
            extensively engaged in providing financial support,
            technical assistance, policy advice, and analytical services
            to Croatia. The Agriculture Acquis Cohesion Project has
            helped the country meet the EU accession requirements in the
            agriculture and rural development areas. About 1,270 new
            jobs have been created in underdeveloped and war-affected
            areas across the country, rebuilding lives and livelihoods
            through activities under the Social and Economic Recovery
            Project. Energy Efficiency Project helped introduce energy
            efficient lighting, heating and thermal insulation in more
            than 50 schools across the country. Throughout its
            engagement in Croatia, IBRD has developed and maintained
            excellent partnerships with key international institutions
            active in the country.Croatia’s per capita income reached
            about 63 percent of the EU average.

docna.cdata!:
Ayudar a Croacia a prepararse para una
            eficaz integración en la Unión Europea

display_title.display_title:
Helping Croatia Prepare for
            Successful European Union Integration : Ayudar a Croacia a
            prepararse para una eficaz integración en la Unión Europea

repnme.cdata!:
Croatia - Helping Croatia prepare for
            successful EU integration

abstracts.cdata!:
Croatia aims to crown fifteen years of
            impressive economic and social progress by joining the
            European Union (EU), but to do so, it will need to bolster
            its economic competitiveness, ensuring Croatians enjoy
            sustainable improvements in their quality of life. The
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
            is helping the government invest in important trade
            infrastructure and research and development initiatives and
            cut red tape, such as the time it takes to register
            property, and support a wide range of social projects,
            ranging from more energy-efficient schools to the removal of
            land mines.

docna.cdata!:
Croatia - Helping Croatia prepare for
            successful EU integration

display_title.display_title:

            for successful EU integration
